Value.Review: DoreWays (for jobs and internships) is a great tool that provides great opportunities!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I feel like a degree from Vanderbilt is going to help me go a long way in the future.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I am very impressed, and its is getting exponentially better
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There a lot of career and job opportunities, we have our own job portal, the career office is very helpful and there are lot of career affiliated clubs, student organizations and public Greek organizations
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
The Arts and Sciences career center is a joke. I only had one friend who used the career services on a regular basis, and he was not able to land a single internship using them. He ended up getting an internship with a bulge bracket investment bank through a family connection.

Generally speaking, if you do not seek out their help, they will not be of any assistance to you. And the school does not host a lot of top companies. The only industries that it is decent at are health care and consulting. Health care is a major industry in Nashville because of the tax incentives offered by the state of Tennessee to health care companies. Consulting is decent because a number of Vanderbilt alumni have gone on to work for major consulting firms. But in reality, none of the classes at Vanderbilt are really that useful for going into consulting. Thus, you're going to have to sell yourself to the consulting firms as a well-rounded generalist.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Going to Vanderbilt can help open many doors.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A Vanderbilt degree carries much more weight than I was originally aware.  Being able to say I am working toward obtaining a degree from Vandy has made looking for internships much easier than anticipated.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Great name on a resume and will really prepare you for what the world expects.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I mean it's a top 20 school. You'll get plenty of job offers, Vanderbilt is definitely worth attending.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I think with a Vanderbilt degree you have a very high chance of finding a job quickly.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They are very generous with financial aid and will usually make the effort to ensure that you can afford to attend.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: If you are accepting into Vanderbilt they will do their best to make sure you can afford to attend.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Freshman year, it was very easy to get the financial aid that I needed. Not sure if this will continue for the next three years, though.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vandy FA is among the best in the country. Many students choose Vanderbilt because it ends up being the cheapest option The financial aid office is cooperative, understanding, and fair. Vandy gave more money than any other school for me, and I appreciate the school's commitment to bringing in the best students it can by nearly eliminating the financial burden for many, making the university affordable for all. Vandy also offers competitive merit scholarships and an automatic 5k for national merit placement. Everyone that needs financial aid should apply to Vandy; it just may end up being the cheapest option!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: People tend to be impressed by a degree from Vanderbilt, but we are not as heavily recruited as Ivies or Duke, which is unfortunate. Most students get good internships and are content with their job placement, but some people struggle to get jobs because Vandy's prestige at workplaces has not yet caught up with the increase in caliber of students. Soon it will.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Vanderbilt meets 100% of your demonstrated financial need, which is amazing.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The school has the money you need, but you have to pursue it. Fortunately, the financial aid officers are very helpful and always willing to work out any problems with you.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Students from here move on to amazing careers all over the world.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I'm broke and I can still afford Vanderbilt.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vanderbilt is as generous as you can get, I think. Tons of scholarships available, and they're rolling out new plans to get aid to as many people who need it.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Financial aid is plenty here, but the process is always annoying.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: If you take advantage of your time here at Vandy, you will go far. The Vandy brand has become great because of the hard work of the students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is a dream at Vandy. Most students receive at least some money. A good number have all of tuition covered. For me, Vandy ended up being cheaper than my local state school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Everyone gets need-based aid up to their "demonstrated need". For the majority, this is fine, but if your parents aren't paying (like mine) or your parents have a lot of money, you may not get all the help you need. They do try to get you out without loans, but I would say it doesn't work all the time.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are a few scholarships to apply for but they are extremely competitive.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Its a highly acclaimed institution whose name carries a great amount of weight in the professional world
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I've heard that the undergraduate programs have much more funding and good scholarships/financial aid. For graduate school I received no scholarships and found that disappointing, although not necessarily surprising. It is a very expensive program but that seems to be the way grad school is anywhere.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: No hitches with the financial aid at the school, I just wish it worked a little differently with scholarships and the grant.  Vanderbilt does provide large grants that make it doable, but there's no denying that there are cheaper schools out there.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vanderbilt is a prestigious school and you are automatically going to be seen as competent by any employer.  With that said the career center really sucks and does very little to help you find an internship or job. 40% of chemical engineers on graduation day last year did not have a job or graduate school secured.  To really get a position anywhere you have to know somebody who knows somebody....but that might just be anywhere you go.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Great financial aid. Bumped my initial award by several thousand dollars.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There is a great range of things to get involved in work wise.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: they give out a bunch
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vanderbilt has a huge endowment that enables it to provide great financial aid to many of its students. They truly do meet all financial need.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They meet all students 100% based on need.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Vandy alums like to hire vanderbilt students
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It is a really great process. They are willing to help out as much as they can. It does not always quite add up, but that is just because of the cost of the school. The difference can be made up for with tiny scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: No loans and all grant aid!!! Very generous grant aid too! It is totally worth getting the bunches of forms in. I wouldn't be able to afford a school like Vandy without their help!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vanderbilt prides itself in the financial aid it provides
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I got offers I didn't expect.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Vanderbilt offers plenty of scholarships and financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I did not qualify for financial aid, but received a full-tuition merit scholarship.  Most of my friends have received aid and Vanderbilt is usually very generous with their financial aid packages.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: From what I hear, almost everyone here is on some form of financial aid. Vandy wants you to come here if you get in, and they'll make it happen
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Vanderbilt gives the best financial aid. No Loans!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is one of Vanderbilt's strong points.  It meets 100% need-based financial aid so they very generously give you the amount of money that you need to attend.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I hear its easy to get a lot of scholarship or financial aid money from Vandy...I have not seen any of it unfortunately.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Great need-based aid; merit-based is difficult
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I recieved a merit scholarship however it was very small. I recieve 5k a year when at many other schools for my accomplishment I was offered a full ride plus an annual stipend, but obviously I chose Vanderbilt. In terms of financial aid, Vanderbilt is pretty good at supplying what you need, however, as is the case with many schools, it's easier for low-income families to get the support they need  instead of middle-income ones.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Vanderbilt usually is known for giving out incredibly generous financial aid
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They give 100% of demonstrated need in financial aid and also give scholarships but I've found that sometimes this is still not enough.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Excellent financial aid services. Sometimes during the busy months, they take some time to respond, but they are always available for questions and are very helpful. Financial aid process is clear.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Vanderbilt has been doing the 100% guarantee to meet demonstrated financial need for the past few years now and it's truly remarkable. I wouldn't be able to go there otherwise, and the same applies to so many other of my very talented and deserving classmates.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
Need-blind, full-need, and no-loan. The three magic phrases for college students who need money to pay for college. The problem is most colleges who offer such generous financial aid packages are also very, very hard to get into. Every Ivy League college, Johns Hopkins, Vanderbilt, Rice, and Washington University are examples. All of the above colleges have one thing in common: A boatload of money. Vanderbilt's endowment for 2012 is $3.4 billion.

The statistics on Vanderbilt's financial aid website are somewhat false. I estimate a good half of the students at Vanderbilt receive $1000 or less in financial aid to pay for their $60,000 cost of attendance because their parents are already making hundreds of thousands, maybe even millions. But guess where the rest of the financial aid budget goes... yes, to the needy!

Several students I know pay $0 to attend Vanderbilt. They get a small stipend every year to cover their living expenses because their families make so little income. The downside is everything at Vanderbilt costs money. Laundry, water, utensils... anything you got for free before will now be deducted from your Commodore Cash or Meal Money accounts.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I recieved enough financial aid so that with a couple outside scholarships Vanderbilt is very affordable.   The school doesn't offer very many opportunities for merit aid, but Vanderbilt had a large endowment so they can afford to offer good financial aid packages.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is wonderful! They do not include loans in the amount declared so anything given by the school does not need to be repaid. Certainly helpful for those who can't afford such a costly school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Vanderbilt need-based financial aid has prided itself on meeting 100 percent of demonstrated need. During my time at vanderbilt, it has been extremely afforable and I am very thankful for that. Although i must admit that it is very annoying to do the css profile and fafsa, but they are both necessary and manditory so do them both as soon as possible.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Amazing Aid – This school has hands down the smoothest financial aid process of any I have come across. You fill out and submit appropriate forms, and, within a few weeks, you get a letter detailing your eligibility for a ton of money. AND- it's money that you don't have to pay back. GANGSTA money.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Vandy doesn't give out many full-rides, but they guarantee 100% demonstrated need-based aid, and they really follow through. So, don't let the price scare you, Vanderbilt will give you what you need without having to take out loans.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They claim they give all students some money but this isn't true. I know my family, and two friends who are all minorities did not receive financial aid and all of us have two children in college. I also know of students who receive plenty so it really could go either way.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: You Can Go Here, No Matter How Much Money You Have – I'm going to Vanderbilt, a top-20 institution and private, out-of-state school, and it's less expensive for me than the University of Georgia (in-state for me) would have been. The financial aid awards are great and totally loan-free, and I've never had a hiccup in the process.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: After completing the necessary forms including FAFSA to apply for financial aid, my family received a generous amount of financial aid and I believe that about 60% of students receive a similar amount of aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Couldn't Be Better – Vanderbilt has THE BEST financial aid around! It is all grant based which means that I won't have to take out loans! I honestly am going to one of the most prestigious universities in the country at a cost lower than that of my state school! The best of both worlds!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are tons of restaurants within walking distance that cover basically every type of food. Taste of Nashville encourages off-campus dining by allowing students to use their meal money at local restaurants, but also tends to funnel everyone to the same ten restaurants when most of the best options aren't part of the program.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food is great for the most part. However, freshmen are forced into an abusive 21 meal/week plan. It's impossible to use all your "swipes" without overeating.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a fairly wide variety of dining options on campus, and if that's still not enough variety for you, you can always use your meal money off campus as well.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's great that for the most part we are able to use our meal money to pay for off-campus dining.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Vanderbilt offers a great variety of foods that caters to different cultures and peoples needs.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Fair amount of options close by. Late night food can be hard to find if you want anything besides pizza or Qdoba, though.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Overall, a lot of the food is high quality. However, the meal plan swipes are way too much food to consume in one sitting. Also, the meal plan periods can be difficult to work around depending on your class schedule.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The amount of food is overwhelming at first, and they have a huge variety. The only problem is walking all that way to get food. They do their best to keep students fed, and the munchie marts are great for snacks and convenient meals
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are so many options on campus it is almost surreal at first. Students become accustomed to how spoiled they are with meal options and are not grateful, but the quality truly is good nearly everywhere. Good Tex Mex, sandwiches, pizza, burgers, fruit, etc. My only complaint is not enough pasta options. The taste o Nashville options are phenomenal too and add to the diversity of great food options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Chipotle, Qdoba, Wendy's, Mellow Mushrom, Dominoe's Papa Johns, Krispy Kreme, Dunkin Donuts, Bruegger's, Chili's, Chuy's, Panera, The Bread Co.,Starbucks, Sweet Cece's, Subway, Quizznos, Smoothie King, Five Guy's the list of chains doesn't end (there are tons more right off campus). There are also tons of non-chains that are great, like the Pancake Pantry, Noshville Deli, Roma's, Sam's Sports Bar, Hattie B's, etc. Nashville has the best food, period. Mostly affordable too.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nashville is such a foodie city, which is wonderful!  Options close around campus can get kind of stale and boring after a while, and without a car, it can be difficult to get out and explore Nashville's food scene.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Overall, Vanderbilt food and dining is really exceptional.  However, Saturdays are the worst.  Hardly anything is open for students.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nashville is a budding city. It is an excellent place for anyone who loves food. Vanderbilt students get to benefit form this with campus being in the heart of the city.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Pub at Vanderbilt is amazing. It really feels like you are at an Irish Pub in downtown Nashville
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is pretty good, and lots of places accept the card. However, off-campus dining can get a little old, especially after the first year.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food here is pretty great. Meal plans are stressful because of limited "swipes" for sophomores and up, and meal time restrictions, but you get used to it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Getting to off campus food is easy and delicious.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the food here. You get tons of choices, and quality food while you're at it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is spectacular. Always hot and fresh cooked for you. All servers have a wonderful smile and make you feel welcome and comfortable
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nashville has a wonderful restaurant scene for any taste and budget. There are decent options near campus, but if you want good food you'll have to drive or uber.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review:
Rand has been getting worse. 

I love spending flex dollars at off campus restaurants!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It's not amazing. Sometimes, the food isn't all that.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nashville is incredible for food. It is an incredibly diverse city with tons of unique and delicious options. Vandy's Taste of Nashville program is a great way to try the cuisine. It allows you to use commodore cash and meal money at select restaurants in the area.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Vandy dining is excellent when it comes to variety of food, location, and their ability to make some really incredible meals. However, quite often your own schedules make it hard to take advantage of these options. I have most of my classes in the Blair School of Music, and I often have to choose between Susie's and Quiznos. It definitely gets old.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nashville has great food! There are a lot of off-campus options that are "on the card" (you can pay with your meal plan), as well as tons of local restaurants. Prices are usually pretty good, and the food is amazing. If you come to campus, try Hattie B's, the Pharmacy, or Pancake Pantry!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are tons of options for food, and while not all of it is good, there are quality options at every dining place. Other than some odd hours, you can pretty much always find good food if that's what you want. Meal plans vary, depending on if you have a kitchen and how much you want to cook.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The restaurants around campus range from fast food to fancy sit down and are all delicious!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Breakfast on commons is delicious! I love the omelets.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Many new independent restaurants opening in Nashville which provided a lot of variety
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are a lot of medium quality options
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Nashville has a large variety of high quality food options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a massive array to choose from at Rand and Commons and the food is extremely high quality. Grins offers high quality vegetarian, kosher options that are as good as restaurant food. Bamboo bistro has delicious pho.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: A lot more options than where I'm from, and many within an acceptable walking distance.  Some chain restaurants, like Chipotle, but no fast food that's really nearby.  I'm okay with that.  There are interesting places to go out and eat and try new things, so I like it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good number of options. There could be more late-night places.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Overall, very good. I haven't been disappointed with my options and there's plenty of food to go around. I just wish there weren't any specific times to use your meal plan. You can only use your meal plan once between 4:30-midnight as the "dinner" swipe, for example. If you want to use another swipe, you have to wait until after midnight or else use flex meals or meal money. 

I just wish there were more options besides Commons during Fall and Spring breaks.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pretty good. I just wish there were more restaurants than Qdoba and Cafe Coco open late.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are many options, but if you don't have a car it's kind of hard to get to.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is good but can get boring after a while. The main dining hall has strange hours and closes early over break.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a great variety just like home; there is something to accommodate everyone.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: There are SO many great restaurants near campus and in the Nashville area.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's Nashville.  Come on...
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: tons of restaurants to choose from. incredible scene
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Same as every other university. Nothing special. It gets old rather quickly. One benefit is that many of these places are on the card, so no money out of my own proverbial pocket has to be taken out.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great deals for the prices. Dining halls can be a little cramped and hard to find seating, but they are generally good. Menu gets really old after a while and food can be pretty gross, but it's not that big a deal and it's survivable. Delivery places are great and the small shops and stores around campus are perfect for when you just don't want the food anymore.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's not NYC or LA, but Nashville has a lot to offer.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Good food and variety, but the hours of operation are not convenient for students. Also the division of the day into meal periods often restricts students from taking advantage of the meal plan.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nashville has a great food culture to it. Countless restaurants and cuisines to explore with more and more being built.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Plenty of fantastic restaurants within walking distance of campus.  Most recommended area is 16th and Edgehill neighborhood, as it has several fantastic spots.  Food can be expensive, but there are certainly worse cities. It never hurts to ask about a student discount.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food options are getting much better thanks to the New Rand dining hall, but there aren't many options around campus.  Rand is pretty much the central go-to place for food
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a few options around campus that are good, but you have to branch out into Nashville to find the best restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food here is extremely good, and there are many options on campus, so that you can diversify your eating habits.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nashville is a foody city. Some of the best food in the country. Tons of great local places (many of which have a great country music environment) and lots of chain restaurants.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nashville has amazing restaurants all within walking distance or even a short drive away. I've been here 4 years and I still haven't tried all of the places I want to eat at.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Vanderbilt dining is one of the best in the country.  We have "meal-money" included in our meal plan each semester that we can use at certain local restaurants near campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Nashville is a very foody city.  Directly around campus there are a bunch of restaurants that are really good.  There are some chain fast food restaurants and Chipotle, etc. but a lot are cool local food options that provide a nice getaway from college food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Your basic stuff: lots of chains and some decent restaurants nearby or within walking distance.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Better than what most of my friends eat at their schools. It's not terribly diverse, but there's always something good available.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Everything nearby is on the card!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Munchie Marts open 24/7=lifesavers during finals
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Incredible. So many options, and a lot of them are on the Commodore Card so you can use Meal Money (part of the meal plan) instead of cash.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Freshman commons has the best food, there's always food available
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: not great for guys because it limits your food per meal, and meals per day. but i guess that helps with the freshman 15 because youre not eating that much
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Especially as a freshman, the walking-distance Hillsboro Village is full of really yummy places such as Fido (taylor swift's favorite, i also see the Nashville stars there all the time), Zumi (best sushi ever), Cabana (holy yum), Jacksons, Frugals (nashville neccessity) and so many more cute little places. We also have bagels and satco and like bricktops and pf changs and PM and like literally everything you can think of and it's all super easy to get to and super delicious, and more often then not, places to eat, even off campus, is on "the card," an infamous piece of plastic that works as a credit card that webasically just treat as monopoly money- (until your parents get the first bill).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It gets a little repetitive but i think it's a lot better than what they have at other schools
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of options but difficult to get to because Vanderbilt deters students from having a car.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Very, very good food. SOOO many options, you can be as healthy or as unhealthy as you want. There is always something good available. Kids love the taste of nashville program.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Campus dining is quite good, and if the traditional cafeterias aren't for you, there are plenty of other ways you can use your meal plan.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: PRetty good. all variety, chains and local in the walls
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There aren't many options and the food is borderline bland.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's hard to get around to find any open restaurants without a car.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We have a ton of options for dining at all times during the day. There are "munchie marts", like little convenience stores, that are open 24/7 on different parts of campus that you can use the meal plan on. There are also many options for meal times including traditional dining halls, cafes, and quick to go options as well, along with a pizza and salad place. The options are endless and there certainly is something for everyone.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Having visited many friends' schools, Vanderbilt's food is really above and beyond what you get at most college cafeterias. Most of the food is fresh made in house, and there is a huge amount of variety in the choices offered. The administration clearly goes out of its way to listen and respond to students' complaints and input. The new locations, including Bamboo Bistro (an Asian cafe) and Pi and Leaf (a brick oven pizza concept) are especially delicious.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Good variety of choices and locations of food provision at ideal locations (spread out, located centrally as well).
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: All the standard fast food options plus several pizza and burger joints. The Hillsboro area just to the south of campus is home to McDougal's fried chicken and the Pancake Pantry, a couple local favorites. If you go a little farther out there are several "hip" new coffee shops and taco bars as well. Students can eat delivery and dine-in at many local restaurants using their campus meal money.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
As a freshman the meal plan is 21 meals/week. Way too much in my opinion. Food options are decent on campus - we have some cafes and large dining halls, as well as a vegan restaurant with the best cheeseburger and a pub with beer. There is also flexible Meal Money with all meal plans that can be used anywhere on campus or at about 20 restaurants off campus. 
After freshman year the compulsory meal plan gets smaller - 14/week for sophomores, 8/week for juniors, none for seniors. You can opt for larger meal plans or buy extra Flex meals (they're usually cheaper in bulk). 
Vanderbilt Dining puts in great effort to get feedback from students, such as updating the Meal Money restaurant selection, or hosting mega themed buffet dining events each semester. Those are awesome treats where the dining hall is all decked out and makes up for the sometimes monotonous offering regularly.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food is really good, usually healthy and tasty.  Meat is often dry though and the menus do get repetitive.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Vanderbilt has in-house dining, which makes the quality of the food better compared to most schools. There are many on campus dining locations so there exists variety in the type of food available. The vegetarian/vegan options are also better than average ("Grins" is an on-campus vegetarian restaurant).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are so many great restaurants in Nashville, and so many are walking distance from campus. What's especially great is that there is this cool program, Taste of Nashville, that Vanderbilt has with almost 30 restaurants around the campus that allows you to use your Commodore Card like a debit card at those places, and a certain amount of Meal Money is added to your card every semester. This makes it easy to go out with your friends to great places like P.F. Chang's or Cabana and not have to always worry about bringing cash with you. On top of that, Hillsboro Village has tons of cute little restaurants, like Pancake Pantry, Fido and Provence Cafe that are always worth a visit. Definitely get your parents to take you to Maggiano's and Pancake Pantry while they're here, and get them to take you to Burger Up at least once - it's the best burger I've ever had in my life.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-campus dining gives you lots of options! From late night (Cafe Coco) to high-end (Sunset, Cabana) to chicken (Prince's and McDougal's), Nashville does food well.  Cheap/cheaper options are easy to find, and many restaurants will accept your Commodore Card (like your school debit card).
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There isn't as wide a variety of readily accessible food options as I'd like, but I have yet to have a bad meal. All of the food is very good and made with care by nice people. The freshman meal plan makes sure that students are always fed as they make the transition to college, but the freshman 15 is not nearly the problem it is made out to be.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are so many great restaurants by campus.  The hillsboro area has lots of one of kind local restuarants especially good for lunch/brunch.  West End has more chains and lots of upscale places that are great for dinner.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There is always something to eat on and around campus!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are so many great restaurants within walking distance of campus in an area called Hillsboro Village and on West End. You can also take a car or cab to many other areas of Nashville with great food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Nashville is a pretty popular place. There are plenty of things within walking distance, and then more choices within a 5minute bus or car ride. Price ranges all over the place from cheap fast food to top notch steak houses and such.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a ton of great restaurants, many within walking distance of Vandy. The restaurants in Hillsborough Village especially are very convenient. People love Fido, a cafe that Taylor Swift frequents. If you have a car, there is amazing barbeque in downtown Nashville, and Loveless Cafe is a must.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The dining options are expensive, but very accessible and diverse.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: You can  around the world in terms of eating options off campus. West End Avenue has over 20 choices alone spanning fast food to pizza to upscale restaurants. Several establishments were featured on Food Network's Diners, Drive ins, and Dives show in 2011-2012. They are student friendly where students also work; the hours are flexible; the cost is reasonable; and the atmosphere is fun.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are many places to eat off-campus. The problem is Vanderbilt money can only be used at about 40 places, you have to walk quite a distance to get there, and most of them are unhealthy fare. Fried chicken, pizza, and Mexican are everywhere.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Most of the previous reviews are about freshman dining. When you become an upperclassman, you realize they serve the same food every day at Rand, where everything tastes frozen. They claim to limit your portion size so they can produce higher quality food, but this is a horrible lie so Vanderbilt can spend less money on food. Vanderbilt dining sucks.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of Choices, on and Off Campus – There are two large dining halls with lots of good options, plus a ton of smaller places on campus. Most "munchie marts" are open 24/7 which is great for weekend late nights. They often sell chick-fil-a or pizza from 12-3am on weekends. When you don't use meals you get roll over into an account that can be used for 10-15 area restaurants off campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: 3 Main Places – Common is on the freshmen campus has the best food. Rand is in the heart of campus everyone goes there for lunch its also connected to Chef James smaller setting slightly better food if you are willing to wait in line.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great Food – Nashville food is amazing. So much deliciousness. There is so much to choose from, and a lot of the restaurants are on the commodore card, which is great. The meal plan comes with meal money that can be spent at these participating restaurants, so it's great to go out and explore the food scene.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Even though Nashville is a southern city, you'll find much more than fried chicken and country-style dinning options. Nashville has a young atmosphere and that is well reflected in the variety of restaurants surrounding the Vanderbilt area. Hillsbourgh village offers smaller, more college-friendly options (by cost and attire) such as bars, quick-dinning sushi at Zumi, and all-america style places like Jacksons, Cabana, and Sunset Grill. While no places that I know of offer consistent student discounts, several of the places in this Hillsbourgh area take the "vanderbilt card"-- students love this. The Downtown area known as the Gulch offers relatively more fine-dinning options. Along west-end, there are several family-style restaurants like Amerigo's and Bricktops, or a large-group favorite like Goten habachi. Historical favorites are also spotted throughout Nashville, such as the speak-easy Patternson House, which despite its high drinks prices, has the absolute best drinks and bartenders in town. Vegetarians, adventure-hunters, and rich Vandy alumni's will all enjoy a little taste of Nashville.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Lots of Variety – Taste of Nashville provides an opportunity to eat off-campus without having to use "real" money. There's something within walking distance for just about anyone. There are several local favorites, like Noshville, as well as bigger chain restaurants if you need something familiar.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Dining Is OK – Dining around Vandy is pretty standard. You have Chili's and TGI Friday's, which are the standard dining spots. But you also have many more restaurants that offer ethnic cuisine.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Fine, Nothing Special – There aren't that many options for dining at Vandy, although if you get creative, you can stay pretty satisfied. The best places in my opinion are the Commons Dining Hall, which has several different choices from a salad bar to Chinese food, and Chef James, which has a different hot entree each day. Although healthy eating isn't the easiest, with a little bit of effort and planning, it's definitely possible. I recommend trying to live off campus, that way you can avoid the meal plan altogether and eat what you want!
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review:
Belmont Kids Are Jealous – The places on-campus are decent, but you have to remember that you are in the south. There's a good chance you'll get a little tired of attempts at biscuits and gravy. The best options as far as variety and taste are the Commons (where all freshmen live), Grins (the only certified Kosher restaurant in middle Tennessee. It's also vegetarian and has fantastic pastries.), and Nectar (the only completely organic place on-campus).
The great thing about the way Vandy's meal plan is set up is that they offer something called Taste of Nashville, which gives students the option to use their meal money at off-campus restaurants, such as Chili's, Qdoba, TGIFriday's, and many more.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Off campus dining is awesome. There's a lot of chain restaurants within walking distance of campus and a decent amount of local ones as well. Many of them participate in Taste of Nashville and can be paid for on the Commodore Card.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Plenty of Places to Eat, on the Card as Well. There's plenty of places to eat off-campus which are on the card as well. A program Vanderbilt University has set up called Tastes in Nashville partners with different restaurants. Each semester, freshman students are allotted $200 in meal money which can be used for ordering online delivery take-out or for going to the different restaurants to eat.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good but Tiring – The Freshman area of campus is host to the better, in my opinion dining hall. The choices are rotated and there are always a lot of options except for the on the weekends. There is a lot to eat from here of the various "munchie marts" on campus. The "upperclass" dining area called Rand is a bit more traditional and the food choices are mediocre but still good. I know there will be more additions in the future. I think 14 meals a week is sufficient for upperclassmen.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Vandy Dining Is Lacking – Rand is the main cafeteria and although they finally redid it, it is still disgusting.  There are not many healthy dining options with fresh food on campus.  For example, one of the few on campus restaurants is a barbecue place which is definitely not good for you and is not good for eating at frequently. The only brandname dining is Quiznos which isn't great.  Vanderbilt forces you to have large meal plans which is expensive so it is very disappointing that it isn't good.  Furthermore, there are lots of great places off campus that are one the card so they should add more meal money into the plans to make it better for students.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Good, Not Great – The food on campus is decent, but the first year students are spoiled.  They get the best dining center, etc.  On main campus, it can be really crowded at meal times and can cause long waits.  Vandy takes initiatives to give the students off-campus options though, which is helpful.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Downtown Food Search – Many places to search for food but really need to search.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Good....If Open – The food isn't bad, especially compared to the food at my friends' schools. However, a lot of places aren't open on campus for a large percentage of the time, which is rough when you're hungry past, say, 7:30 at night, or at all on the weekends.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Heart of Nashville – Being in the heart of Nashville, there's plenty of great dining around campus, from fast food, to quick-but-good eats, to nice sit down dining, you can find great dining off campus, but a lot of it is pricy.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Good Variety in Price and Type of Food – There are many places to eat within walking distance of campus. There isn't a huge variety in type of food, but there is in price and atmosphere. I personally love the off-campus dining around campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Dining Is Good for a College Campus – Compared to all of my friends reviews of their college dining, I think the food and options at Vanderbilt are excellent. We have the Pub where you can always get burgers/fun atmosphere, Grins which is vegetarian, and Rotiki which has sandwiches/paninis/etc. Having Quiznos on meal plan is also really ncie. The only problem I have with dining is that our main dining hall (Rand) is too small/unable to cope with the amount of students coming in at lunch time. Also why isn't Rand open for dinner every night? That makes no sense to me...
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Meal Money Is Good – Meal plans that include meal money are great and a lot of local restaurants close to campus accept it, and it works just like cash. However, there is a large push by students to continually expand the program to other restaurants to compensate for the university dining halls weird hours.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms are great!  The new dorms - Kissam, were really nice as well. Currently living in an apartment style dorm with three other student and I really like this set up.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Freshman housing on the commons is very good as the buildings are very new and they are close to a dining hall, but with the exception of Morgan and Lewis and the dorms on Highland Quad there are some very old dorms and some like blakemore are very far from main campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I lived in Gillette which is probably the worst of the Commons houses, but there were still never any major troubles with cleanliness or maintenance. It certainly wasn't Hank or Stambaugh, though!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Vanderbilt students are required to stay on campus all four years, with the exception of some seniors.  I love this rule because I think it creates a strong sense of community.  The freshman dorms are amazing! All the freshman stay on the same part of campus called "The Commons."  It consists of ten houses which are the dorms and the Commons Center, which holds the dining hall, a minimart, the gym, and study rooms.  An esteemed faculty member is chosen for each of the houses, and they stay in the houses with the students and serve as "The Head of House."  I really enjoyed living on Commons because I think it truly helps with the freshman adjustment.  You get to live separately from the rest of campus with everyone in your class, and it's comforting to be with everyone else who's is brand new, unfamiliar and going through a lot of the same things as you are.  It also helps to foster strong friendships because everyone is located so close.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Have yet to inhabit it, so I cannot give an accurate review.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Some of the newer dorms are ridiculously spacious and nice, while the old one's aren't. It's as one would expect.

What's kinda a bummer for me is you're not allowed to live off campus until senior year MAYBE, which I would much prefer, but I do like the residential community vibes and how close my dorms have been to classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great for freshmen, juniors, and seniors. Sophomores get a bit left out.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman year has been good but we'll see what happens as I become an upperclassman.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is incredible - a great sense of community, amazing rooms, and it's close to food and activities. Once you leave freshman year, though, they kind of don't care. Unless you're lucky enough to make it in Kissam or Highland quad or get a spot off campus, every other option is a little scary. Like. Really. Cockroaches and dirty community bathrooms and flooding type of scary.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It's great, but a little expensive
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I don't live in the best housing. But my residences so far have not been horrific.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The Ingram commons for freshman year are amazing. They build such a great sense of community and food is very close. Also, coed floors are a good time
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: It allows students to succeed, while having fun at the same time.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Commons freshman year is great but Scomb is smaller than most freshman houses
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: some dorms are aboslutely terrible and others are very good and hard to get into.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Better than any other school I visited by far, I am very pleased
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is great, especially on commons: most of the housing facilities are new and they're planning to bring down more of the older dormitories and campus to build new ones
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshmen all live on the commons, which is a great way to meet other freshmen. All of the commons dorms are very close to the commons center which has a dining hall and gym. Generally, the freshmen dorms are very nice and spacious, with the exception of a few of the older buildings.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living off-campus was far better than living on-campus at Vanderbilt. The dorms could have been more spacious, but at least they are new.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The Commons are very nice, but there are few good options for Upperclassmen. Housing selection is a nightmare.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The newer dorms (Commons, Kissam) are amazing housing options. The rest are still better than typical college dorms, but some dorms are pretty lacking. The lottery is just that - annoying to those that 'lose,' and awesome for those that 'win.' It's a pain that only a few seniors are granted off-campus housing, but Vandy tries to optimize the spaces on campus that they provide.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review:
The implementation of Kissam is a disaster.  The lottery system used is not based on seniority like the rest of the campus. Additionally, the lottery is not as random as the school wishes you to believe, they have a male/female ratio that they maintain regardless of how the dice roll (look at an article written in the hustler a while back).

Additionally, a few of the dorms are in disrepair (Vandy/Barnard has a SERIOUS mold problem). Overall, however, when speaking generally housing is quite good at vandy comparative to other institutions. 

Rule enforcement at vandy can be characterized as nothing less than "fascistic" on commons and in Kissam. However this varies from dorm to dorm more generally speaking. VUPD will not hesitate to bust a student for minor infractions as well. 

However, everything else is in tip-top shape. The campus is BEAUTIFULLY maintained. Buildings are left unlocked so that students may have late night study or movie screenings! The campus is also basically a park in the middle of Nashville, so it is hard to complain.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Commons has been awesome - you're surrounded by people who are in the exact same situation as you! I've been in other halls as well, housing varies, but it's overall pretty nice!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I currently live on Commons and while it is proclaimed one of, if not , the best housing on campus, not all the houses are great. The house I live is not great compared to other Commons houses.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is the best but there are good options as an upper classman
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in the best dorms so I have nothing to complain about; however, there are pretty crappy dorms as well.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most dorms are of at least acceptable quality. The biggest issue is that it's very hard to get permission to live in cheaper and nicer off-campus options.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The majority of students live on campus, so the school makes an effort to keep the living conditions of dorms fairly well. For upperclass housing, Kissam is the best option, while Vandy Barnard is the worst.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Vanderbilt incorporates a great community that caters to its students.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Very, very expensive. Vanderbilt does not let many people live off campus at all, so it is mostly rich kids with connections who are able to get off campus apartments.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman dorms are fairly large and nice; some upperclassman dorms are nice also, but some are poor quality. Social atmosphere varies; it can be awkward as a freshman, but once you are an upperclassman and can choose to live near your friends, though, the social atmosphere is very fun.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The campus is beautiful, and it's nice to walk through an arboretum to class everyday. The freshman dorms are by far the nicest Vanderbilt has to offer and they spoil the first years. Upperclassmen housing isn't as nice (except for our brand new Kissam), but everything is closer once you move to main campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman dorms are unbelievable, and the commons fosters a great, friendly community.Upperclassmen have a few really good options, but can also get the short end of the stick. Overall, dorms are significantly better than at most schools I've seen.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Overall, the housing is decent.  However, it's unfair that some of the dorms are drastically nicer than others.  Also, the lottery system is a bit difficult to work through, considering that a student may need to switch roommates and look or drop other individuals because of the random lottery.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Vanderbilt encourages students to stay on campus all 4 years. This option actually saves money and the housing is amazing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Vanderbilt University is one of the best undergraduate universities in the nation. The housing at Vanderbilt is amazing which is why most students choose to live on campus for all four years. Being in the heart of Nashville, a budding city, the students at Vanderbilt always have an opportunity to do interesting things. The housing process at Vanderbilt is extremely easy. You simply fill out a quick survey and you are done!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The rooms are fantastic, for the most part. All are really big and pretty clean. However, the housing process is very difficult to navigate, and after the first year the process basically gives you the worst of what campus has to offer (which, relatively speaking, is still pretty nice).
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Only seniors live off-campus because Vanderbilt requires on-campus living.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The housing at Vanderbilt isn't cheap and it isn't huge, but the atmosphere of the dorms is great. I met my best friends on my floor, and have a great relationship with people in my house. You won't get you own bathroom, and you won't get tons of space, but the housing is great because of the people.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are wonderful dining halls that serve amazing food. The dorms are nice and spacious, as well as in close proximity to each other which allows more social interaction. Stambaugh is best
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Not worth it, cool if you want to have parties but downtown is expensive. Further away is pretty good price but you'll need a car and parking on campus is expensive
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Best option is Mctyeire - oldest dorm on campus that has its own dining facility, offering buffet breakfast 5x/week and buffet dinner 4x/week. Only catch is you have to speak a foreign language or be interested in international affairs, but you've got single rooms and a wonderful close-knit community!
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is just cheaper. Just live on campus. Everyone does.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Campus housing is pretty good. Living on the Commons is fantastic and top of line in terms of first year housing. As an upperclassmen quality of housing varies, but over all it is well maintained. Most students live on campus all four years, so the social environment in housing is great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Because the majority of students live on campus, it's a great community experience, and with the exception of the worst dorms, they are pretty nice. There are lots of options for suites or houses for upperclassmen, and the Commons (freshman) housing is one of the best options.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Not many people live off campus because there aren't many options
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman dorms are awesome! But upperclassmen get the older and less nice ones
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The brand new freshman dorms were incredible.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The facilities are spacious and luxurious. Many different options.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Although they are trying to improve the dorms for the most part the upperclassmen housing is pretty awful.  Rooms are incredibly small and most of the dorms are incredibly outdated.  It can(not always) be cheaper than living off campus so most people just deal with it.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
Commons is great; new buildings and great social atmosphere that fosters friendships. Apart from Commons, everywhere else is generally dead. Nobody likes to venture out of their rooms to meet or hang out with others who live in the same building. McGill is the exception to this, but in terms of building quality and cleanliness, every single residence hall needs to be renovated. There's mold and a musty smell in at least one corner of each building. I have yet to find a building other than Kissam or Commons where students do not need dehumidifiers. In my res hall, there's no thermostat, so you're stuck between frigid AC when the temp is >55 degrees and sweltering heaters when <55 degrees, both on full blast. 

The dorms also need more and better social spaces. Almost every floor in every hall is nothing but corridors, which leaves no space for socializing or studying with others on the same floor. Recreation rooms in the residence hall have very few amenities (e.g. Tolman has only a foosball table in its basement). Study spaces are almost non-existent.

The only downside to Commons is its distance from main campus. As for upperclass housing, Morgan/Lewis seem to be the best in terms of cleanliness and space. The major downside to the "nice" housing, however, is the distance from everything except the gym and Blair. Basically, you pick between quality and convenience.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I love the Freshman Commons! It's nice that all of the freshman are separate from the rest of the campus. It's just far away from main campus, and a big switch once you move to sophomore year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Grad students split a house and car pool in for classes. A little further from campus is more reasonable housing cost.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Very clean, very spacious, nice place to study and one can fill safe
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is only allowed for a few seniors once on campus housing is full.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I was very lucky with my first year dorm. Everything is random at Vanderbilt for freshman. For the most part, the dorms are all pretty good. About half are very nice and spacious, and the others it just depends on the room. The bigger nicer ones house more people as well.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: If you can get off campus then you will find some fun places but... good luck getting approved
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I loved being in Branscomb.  Right in the middle of campus with close proximity to greek life and classes.  New dorms are unbelievable... too bad I didn't get to stay in them
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Some really nice new buildings. Wish they didnt make you stay on campus
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: wish theyd let more students go off campus
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review:
It honestly depends on where you live. Freshman housing is 100% perfect in terms of quality and amenities, but about 15 minutes of a walk away from main campus. And the other dorms vary. The newer or more recently renovated, the greater the amenities, spaciousness, perks and quality of the dorm. The older the dorm, the worse the rooms and facilities. The upperclassman housing are basically around the perimeter of the academic buildings and halls, so getting to the dorms isn't hard. There are limited options for housing for sophomores with most being either smack dab in the middle of the horrible frat row or in shabby, old dorms. As an upperclassman, your best option will be Morgan and Lewis (the downside being nearby the stadium, bad parking and horrible traffic on game weeks which is frequent). Your worst is Vandy Barnard (or "Barnyard" if you will). 

Cost, social atmosphere, and ballots are the same no mater where you apply, so those don't really matter.

Amenities include laundry, kitchens (not fully stocked), lounges, music rooms for some dorms, etc. The best dorms have full amenities; the worst are only missing ones that aren't as necessary, but they still have the basics.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I don't live off-campus, but I have visited apartments in the area and they are wonderful. If the school had not established that ridiculous rule where you can only live off-campus if you are a senior, I am sure there would be many students with apartments off-campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are great. There are so many spaces available with so much option for where you want to live. The only downside is not being able to live off campus, because the on-campus social atmosphere can be too much partying for someone who is not really into that scene.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing would be pretty good except for the fact that it is not available to any students except for a handful of seniors this year. They make it very difficult to get away if you want to.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I haven't lived off campus before so I'm not the person to ask
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I've enjoyed the campus housing. Kissam also just opened.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Nashville has great off-campus housing options (houses, apartments, town homes, etc.) but the school refuses to approve students to live off-campus. The Residential Requirement to live on-campus is disapproved by the majority of the student body.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I'm not sure of specifics, but like I said before, basically everyone lives on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: 97% of students live on campus all four years, so I think it's pretty great.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is cheaper, nicer and just as convenient.  There are several apartment complexes that are a shorter walk to classroom buildings than many of the dormitories.  Highly recommended.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Housing is very good, especially now that they've torn down Kissam Quad.  The Commons, of course, are fantastic in terms of amenities, access and social atmosphere, and are where many long-term friendships are made.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Since being here, they've made major improvements to existing housing and are building new housing that is state-of-the-art.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most of the options are expensive around campus, so you have to do a lot of searching to find more affordable options.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Branscomb and some of the older upperclassmen dorms suck, but Kissam opening should make a lot of people happy this next year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are a lot of different options of places to live, which is really nice.  Housing is expensive but they do really try to make the experience positive.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It can be hard to get approved for off-campus housing by the university, but the apartments and townhouses themselves are really nice.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is great for freshmen, but I hear it gets worse as you get older in terms of how clean and old the buildings are.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Everyone lives on campus, so community is huge!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is great, upperclassman living is above average
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing on campus is close to all classes, clean, and nice.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is among the best in the country as you basically live in a spacious hotel, but as the years progress housing gets worse. Most sophomores live in Branscomb right now and everyone else either lives in the mayfields or towers or off campus until new kissam opens and then everyone will want to live there. Depending on how that looks, housing for upperclassmen might be better.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing gets worse as you get older, which is disappointing. But generally housing isn't so bad.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman Commons is beautiful, but upperclassman housing is a step down.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most kids live off campus senior year if at all. A lot of good popular options that everyone knows about by the time they are seniors.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The Commons have beautiful dorms. Housing does go down after freshman year, but the new dorms at Kissam should make high quality housing available for sophomores, juniors, and seniors as well.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's awesome, but it varies. Older places are not as great, but Vandy is building lots of new dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Pretty expensive. Hard to find a good place to live unless you have a lot of money or unless you have friends living nearby. Otherwise, everything is within a good walking distance
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms aren't the best but they're definitely not bad. There's a floor in North house (freshmen) that has private bathrooms which is like winning the lottery. Wish the school had more of these for freshmen. The Mayfield's are in my opinion the best housing option. They are ten-person houses that have only singles and can be coed. Didn't care for the freshman bubble living experience though. Unless you're actively rushing, you probably wont meet a ton of upperclassman.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms are great. All freshmen live together on the Commons, which has its own student center/dining hall/munchie mart. Upperclassmen have plenty of options, and none of them are awful. The dorm I live in is kind of old, but I have a kitchen, bathroom, living room, and bedroom and only one roommate. Upperclassmen can find something more than suitable if they understand the lottery/ballot process. Vanderbilt tore down its oldest dorms last year and replaced them with new ones which will be open for 2014-15.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review:
The freshman dorms (Commons) are amazing. Half of them are only a few years old and have tall ceilings. Some are smaller but the Commons program makes it feel very warm and welcoming. Each Commons dorm (there are 10) has its own faculty head whose family lives in the building - feels like Hogwarts! 
Upperclassmen get to ballot for housing - there are seniority points. Huge range of options from location to atmosphere to housing type - 2, 4, 6 person apartments, or singles/double rooms. Most buildings are co-ed with single-sex floors, but there are co-ed apartments and single-sex buildings too. There are also special learning environments you have to apply for which involve some participation over the school year (Mctyiere for foreign languages, Mcgill for independent projects, Vandy-Barnard for Leadership or Creativity, and Mayfield 10-person houses with special projects). 
Since the cost is the same for all these places, it really allows you to pick somewhere to live based on your preference and not cost.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Very hard to get off campus housing, and when you can, it is usually quite far away.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Commons is amazing for freshmen. After that there are better options for people who want suites/ singles/ or a kitchen and bath inside their dorm but the quality of the housing is not as good. I wish each room had a sink, and each floor had a kitchen/ study room available for resident use.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on Commons your freshman year will be fantastic - the ten houses are all really really nice dorms (all either renovated or built in the past 10 years), and it's a nice experience having a faculty head of house living in the dorm. There are lots of options for upperclassmen housing to, although none of them quite beat Commons. They're also building an entire new quad of upperclassmen dorms that are set to open in the fall of 2014. Housing is on the pricier side here, but compared to a lot of other schools, it's like living in a hotel. Living Learning Communities are also a cool thing to check out for upperclassmen.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The housing is in order and timely. The facilities are well-kept with custodial services. There are renovations going on now. You will feel comfortable and at home. Much better than many other schools.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The process to applying, finding, and funding off campus housing is so arduous and lengthy.  My roommate and I started the process, but got overwhelmed and realized it wasn't as good of a deal as we had originally thought. Plus, the ones that are close to campus fill up early, so one will also have to have a car (more expenses) in order to travel back and worth. I suggest on campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing for freshman is the best on campus.  The dorms actually look like hotels inside.  For upperclassmen the dorms are atill nice, but just not as showy.  There are also Mayfields for upperclassmen that house 10 students with a project.  These are very popular and competitive to get into.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshmen dorms are great, but once you become an upperclassman, it's not that great. Small spaces, smelly atmospheres, thin doors.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms are brand new beautiful but all of the upper classmen dorms are from the 60s.  Most people live on campus all 4 years and your junior and senior years you can live in dorms that are apartment style with their own kitchens and bathrooms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Everyone starts out on commons which offers the nicest housing and amenities on campus. Freshman dorms are all redone and/or brand new and have everything you could need and more. Softmore year and up housing gets a little sketchy in terms of how nice the dorms are. Vanderbilt guarantees four years of housing which is very nice. Somethings you'll notice as a student at Vanderbilt is that even though the housing gets worse the older you get, the leniency and location get better. Commons is great but RAs are strict and its pretty far removed from main campus. Softmore housing at Branscomb is right in the middle of everything and people seem to have a lot more fun and freedom.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshman housing is great, but the upperclassman housing is not as good. Basically, freshmen are spoiled. However, they are in the process of rebuilding Kissam, which should be ready in 2016, and it's supposed to be really nice.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I would say the off campus housing here is pretty good. A lot of the apartments off campus actually cost less than housing on campus. Normally Vanderbilt wants students to stay on campus for at least their first three years of college, but because of the closing of Kissam Quad in 2012, we have had a shortage of available rooms for all students, so the administration had to let students live off campus even if they are not seniors.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms, called The Commons, are the best dorms I have seen offered to freshman.  The buildings that make up The Commons are either newly built or recently renovated.  The upperclassman options, like Towers, Highland, or Branscomb are great options for upperclassman because of the apartment style rooms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman year the housing is great, but every year that follows has a lot to live up to. The first year experience is fantastic, but the housing is not completely terrible once you get of the "Commons".
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshmen all live on the Commons in 10 different houses. The Commons are definitely the nicest dorms on campus and most of them are either new or newly renovated. Sophomores mainly live in Branscomb, which is loud and right across from Greek row. It is probably the least nice dorm on campus, but its not bad at all. Junior and Senior housing is nicer and transitions to apartment or suite style. In the next few years there will be a new set of dorms replacing Kissam, which they knowcked down last year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Freshman live in awesome housing, but have to walk for 15-20 minutes for any class on the main campus. Upperclassmen have many choices, but most of them are bad. For the short version, go to Towers for partying, or Vanderbilt and Barnard for studying.

The most social dorm is Carmichael Towers West, where people live in large suites and party hard on the weekends. Towers East is also very social, but has more single rooms and a few doubles. The Branscomb Quadrangle is yet another party dormitory due to being in close proximity to Fraternity Row, and thus houses many brothers and sisters. Vanderbilt and Barnard halls are connected and have spacious single and double rooms, with a less raging party scene than any of the above. Highland Quad has very large suites (4 or more people) and is located far away from everything, but is very quiet. Blakemore House is the newest dormitory on campus but is also far away from everything; I would assume things are quiet there as well, and very nice. Cole and Tolman are the women and men only dorms, but I know very little about them. McTyeire residents are required to speak in a foreign language (they are either international or anti-social) and are forced eat dinner there on a regular basis, but everything there is new and clean due to being renovated 20 years ago. Greek Row has nice houses in plain sight of everybody who walks on campus. Last, Kissam Quadrangle is being rebuilt, and sure to be amazing in two or three years.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Mixed Bag – There some awesome newly remodeled/built dorms, and some that are old, inconvenient or both.  They knocked down the worst houses, but they haven't rebuilt so housing will be tight for awhile, which means the the normally 3-person rooms will hold 4, etc.   Freshmen could be in spacious single rooms, or crowded triples (like I was) and upper-classmen have some good options, but some still end up less than great situations because of the lottery.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Apartments Are Somewhat Affordable – Depending on what you earn, Nashville has a variety of housing options that could meet what you can afford. The only problem is proximity to the campus. That said, apartments are relatively easy to find and the landlords/realtors are very nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Not the Best Option – Off campus housing can be difficult to find especially for a college student without a full time job, besides the fact that you have to get permission to live off campus. on campus housing is a much better option.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshmen Have It Made; Upperclassmen Not So Much – Students are spoiled their 1st year by living on the Commons; after that it's a crapshoot.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off campus is expensive! On campus is definitely the way to go.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing is always being improved, and the options available are good for the most part. However, the university is definitely investing a lot of money into building better upperclassmen housing, so if you're graduating high school in 2013 or later, you're in great shape.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Spoiled as Freshmen – The Commons (freshman campus built in 2008) are by far the nicest dorms I've seen at any school, and we are so spoiled to get to live there as freshmen. And while upperclassmen dorms are outdated, I loved living in the sophomore Branscomb quad because you are at the heart of campus and completely connected to every dorm there. Also, half the rooms are connected with bathrooms which is great. They are now rebuilding the other half of sophomore housing, so that will be great when its finished but will create some problems until then. Junior/senior housing in Towers is great because its suite-style with own bathrooms, kitchens, and a main room. Morgan/Lewis upperclassmen housing is nice suites also, just in a worse location.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Expensive and Same Price for Each Kind of Housing – expensive. Good housing for freshman but the ones for upperclassmen vary in quality.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great Housing – The pricing of the dorms and atmoshphere are all great! The best living situation is the freshmen housing. The social atmoshpere is excellent and makes a great first year experience to college.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms at Vanderbilt are great but it goes downhill from there. This may not stay true for long because of the new housing initiatives on campus that will bring about massive renovation to upperclassmen dormitories.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Don't Bother – Off campus housing is extremely discouraged at Vanderbilt - the administration tries very hard to promote the idea of residential education sustained through the entire undergraduate career. You can live in the Wesleys or Village at Vanderbilt, but usually only as a senior, and you will be part of a very small minority. Costs are comparable to on-campus housing, and the locations are pretty safe and close by.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshmen... welcome to Hogwarts! You will be pampered living on the Commons, getting to your classmates as you work, study, sleep, eat, and party together for a fantastic year on an eco-friendly and glitteringly green campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Many Options – Off campus housing is still very close and affordable around the vanderbilt campus. Some of the best housing is by Peabody College of Education part of campus for everyone interested in graduate work as well.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Apartment Availability Is Low – The best way to go in Vanderbilt is with an actual house off campus.  There are very few apartments available near by and the demand for those apartments is so high that the price is out of range.  The best way to go is to get a group and move into a house.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: First Year Housing Is Ridiculously Amazing – Vanderbilt has an amazing housing system for first year students: the Commons. The Commons is still on Vanderbilt's campus (Peabody campus to be more precise) but is separated from the upperclassmen dorms. It consists of 10 dorms: 5 newly renovated and 5 brand new. The brand new ones are nicer, but the newly renovated ones are great too (and a little closer to main campus, where most people's classes are). The rooms are mostly doubles, and each room has its own thermostat. The Commons gets lots of funding and has tons of activities and programming for students.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on the Commons – The dorms where most sophomores get stuck are all singles, small, and in an awful location.  However, the freshman, who all live on the commons, have excellent dorms with their own dining hall and workout facility.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Many Options – The Nashville area provides many affordable options for off campus housing
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: It All Depends on Your Luck – The cost is INSANELY expensive, but the perks of living on campus are worth it (not that you have much of a choice). The dorms on the Commons are amazing and are definitely the best on campus.  Sophomores don't have the best choices; you get placed in Kissam (old but not as bad as people say), Branscomb (party dorm), a house or Alumni lawn (definitely the best single option), or if you're lucky, you can get Morgan or Mayfield.  These are all a serious downgrade from the Commons, but the location makes up for it. The housing process is interesting, but it all comes down to luck.  It's easy to change if you really hate where you end up, especially if your parents are involved. The four year on-campus rule is stupid, but it promotes a really tight-knit student body.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore
